body:
I accepted this without separate confirmation because I know we have some special code for a single array argument. We may not deal correctly with a single params argument.

We're close to releasing 3.2, so this may not make the cut, but we ought to try.

That would be great. It currently leaves my Continuous Testing Session in an unfinished state with 1 dirty (pending) test: The problem is not there, when I use a "proper" array: ``` csharp [Test] [TestCase(new int[] { })] [TestCase(new int[] { 1 })] [TestCase(new int[] { 1, 2, 3 })] public void TestMethod(int[] array) { Assert.That(array, Is.Not.Null); } ``` But that makes it difficult to read, as all test cases show up as three test cases with the same signature of `TestCase(System.Int32[])`, which makes them difficult to differentiate. With VS and NUnit test adapter: And with ReSharper: Slightly off topic: is there a way to see when 3.2 is planned for?
@lundmikkel Looking back at this, I noticed your reference to a "Pending" test in R#. What is a "pending test?" It's not a term I've used and definitely not an NUnit test status.

This turns out to be a test naming irregularity in NUnit itself, not merely in the adapter. Fixing it may actually help R# as well.

My guess about "Pending" is that it's a test that was found by R# in the source but was never run. I'm assuming that it's R#'s logic that applies in finding the test and our code for reporting it as run. If that's true, the R# error should be fixed by correcting the name NUnit generates for the test.

I honestly don't know what pending tests are (Google search didn't help a lot). All I know is that pending tests are a nightmare. I have no clue what causes them in general. I've seen pending tests with `TestCase`s, where the individual `TestCase`s are not run, unless you run them individually/manually.

I'm not sure how this relates to the issure, but it seems you might have a better idea :) It would be great if you find a fix for NUnit that fixes ReSharper as well.

As a semi-intelligent guess, I'd say it's a test that R# expected to see run but which was never reported. Instead, an unexpected test (with the array argument) is reported. To ensure that nothing is forgotten, it reports on both the expected-but-not-reported and the unexpected test. Visual Studio will do the same if a test is discovered under one name but executed under another. It doesn't happen in this case, because NUnit performs both operations for VS.

I can see what's causing this in our code, so it's matter of doing some refactoring and putting in the fix for NUnit 3.2. The next release of the NUnit 3 VS Test Adapter will reflect the change. If it's possible for you to substitute NUnit 3.2 for the version used by R#, then you should see the impact there as well. Same goes for any other 3rd party tools.

issue.title: Make Arguments a separate array from OriginalArguments
issue.body: This fixes #1282. It turns out that OriginalArguments and Arguments were both references to the same array, so that when the content of the Arguments array was modified for certain cases, the OriginalArguments were also modified, defeating the entire purpose of having two properties.

body:
I'd say this last example is a problem with Resharper failing to understand how NUnit names tests. They are assuming a naming convention that was used with NUnit V2, where the name of the base class was added to the name. This is not done in V3.

The original problem was a case where NUnit was not correctly following it's own naming conventions. That is fixed in the PR referenced above, which is currently being reviewed.
Okay, this seems to already be an issue with ReSharper: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/RSRP-453433.

issue.title: Standardise behaviour of params and optional arguments across parameterised attributes
issue.body:
NUnit has various parameterised arguments, which make various special conversions to adjust parameters to match method signatures, to allow invocation via reflection. The key ones I'm thinking of are `[TestCase()]`, `[TestCaseSource()]`, `[TestFixture()]` and `[TestFixtureSource()]`.

Support for params and optional arguments between these attributes is inconsistent. Over the years, this has raised various issues:
https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1281 (open)
https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1883 (open)
https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1459 (open)
https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1640
https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1278
https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1282
https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/257

We've talked in a couple of places ([link 1](https://github.com/nunit/nunit/pull/2104), [link 2](https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1281), [link 3](https://github.com/nunit/nunit/pull/1850)) about harmonising this functionality, and having a single utility class, which resolves parameters passed to attributes, and ensures they are handled in a standard manner across all attributes. As I remember - this was something we agreed to go ahead with - @Yarmonov started on a PR in https://github.com/nunit/nunit/pull/2104. (This seems to have gone stale, unfortunately. Will check in on it shortly.) This would mean that the params keyword and optional arguments would be handled in a standard fashion across all of these attributes, meaning no unexpected surprises for the end-user. 

I wanted to create a master issue for this whole idea - as some of the existing open issues are tagged easyfix - and I didn't want anyone to end up implementing any more solutions individually, when we actually want to be sharing the existing functionality between attributes. If @nunit/framework-team agree - I'd like to close the open issues above, and use this as a single issue to reflect the overall plan.
